name: Shark
quickFacts: Sharks have existed for over 400 million years
There are over 500 species of sharks
Only about 10 species are considered potentially dangerous to humans
ecologicalBenefits: Maintain healthy ocean ecosystems by controlling prey populations
Remove sick and weak fish, keeping populations strong
Help preserve seagrass beds by preventing overgrazing

myths.myth: Sharks are man-eaters that hunt humans
myths.fact: Sharks rarely attack humans. Most attacks are cases of mistaken identity, where sharks confuse surfers or swimmers with their natural prey. Humans are not part of sharks' natural diet.

myths.myth: All sharks are dangerous and should be feared
myths.fact: Out of over 500 shark species, only a handful pose any threat to humans. Most sharks are small, harmless, and prefer to avoid human contact entirely.

myths.myth: Sharks must keep swimming to breathe
myths.fact: While some sharks need to swim to force water over their gills (ram ventilation), many species can pump water over their gills while stationary, allowing them to rest.

name: Bat
quickFacts: Bats are the only mammals capable of sustained flight
There are over 1,400 species of bats worldwide
A single bat can eat thousands of insects in one night
ecologicalBenefits: Provide natural pest control, saving farmers billions in pesticides
Pollinate over 300 species of fruit
Disperse seeds that help restore deforested areas

myths.myth: All bats carry rabies and are dangerous
myths.fact: Less than 1% of bats carry rabies, and they avoid humans. Bats are not aggressive and will only bite if handled. Like all wildlife, observe from a distance.

myths.myth: Bats are flying rodents that are dirty
myths.fact: Bats are not rodents—they're their own order (Chiroptera). They're actually very clean animals that groom themselves regularly, similar to cats.

myths.myth: Bats are blind and will get tangled in your hair
myths.fact: Bats have excellent eyesight and use echolocation to navigate. They are highly skilled flyers and can easily avoid obstacles, including your head.

name: Spider
quickFacts: There are over 45,000 known spider species
Spiders eat more insects than birds and bats combined
Most spiders are harmless to humans
ecologicalBenefits: Natural pest control for agricultural crops
Reduce disease-carrying insects like mosquitoes
Help maintain ecosystem balance

myths.myth: All spiders are venomous and dangerous
myths.fact: While most spiders have venom, very few are dangerous to humans. Out of thousands of species, only a small number can cause significant harm, and they rarely bite unless threatened.

myths.myth: Spiders crawl into your mouth while you sleep
myths.fact: This is a complete myth. Spiders avoid humans and have no interest in crawling into mouths. The average person swallows zero spiders in their lifetime while sleeping.

myths.myth: Daddy longlegs are the most venomous spiders
myths.fact: Daddy longlegs (harvestmen) aren't even true spiders, and they don't have venom glands. They're completely harmless to humans.

name: Vulture
quickFacts: Vultures are found on every continent except Antarctica and Australia
They have incredibly strong stomach acid
Vultures can spot a dead animal from over a mile away
ecologicalBenefits: Nature's cleanup crew—prevent spread of disease
Remove carcasses that could contaminate water sources
Reduce greenhouse gases by quickly disposing of dead animals

myths.myth: Vultures are dirty and spread disease
myths.fact: Vultures actually prevent disease by quickly consuming dead animals. Their digestive systems destroy harmful bacteria, including anthrax and botulism, making them nature's sanitizers.

myths.myth: Vultures are ugly and useless
myths.fact: Vultures are essential ecosystem engineers. Without them, dead animals would rot for weeks, spreading disease and contaminating water sources. They're beautiful in their efficiency.

myths.myth: Vultures attack living animals
myths.fact: Vultures exclusively eat carrion (dead animals). They have weak feet and beaks designed for scavenging, not hunting. They pose no threat to living animals or humans.

name: Hyena
quickFacts: Hyenas are more closely related to cats than dogs
They have the strongest bite force of any mammal
Female hyenas are larger and more dominant than males
ecologicalBenefits: Efficient scavengers that clean up carcasses
Control populations of herbivores
Help cycle nutrients back into the ecosystem

myths.myth: Hyenas are cowardly scavengers that only steal kills
myths.fact: Hyenas are successful hunters—they kill 60-95% of what they eat. They're also intelligent pack hunters capable of taking down large prey like wildebeest and zebras.

myths.myth: Hyenas are evil and laugh at their victims
myths.fact: Hyena 'laughter' is actually a complex communication system indicating social status and excitement. They're highly social, intelligent animals with complex family structures.

myths.myth: Hyenas are dangerous man-eaters
myths.fact: Hyenas rarely attack humans and typically avoid human settlements. When attacks do occur, they're usually due to habitat loss forcing encounters, not natural aggression.

name: Wolf
quickFacts: Wolves live in packs with complex social structures
They can travel up to 30 miles in a single day
Wolves rarely attack humans—there are fewer than 10 fatal attacks per decade worldwide
ecologicalBenefits: Maintain healthy prey populations through selective hunting
Prevent overgrazing by controlling herbivore numbers
Create trophic cascades that benefit entire ecosystems

myths.myth: Wolves are bloodthirsty killers that hunt for fun
myths.fact: Wolves hunt for survival, not sport. They selectively target weak, sick, or old animals, which strengthens prey populations. They consume almost everything they kill.

myths.myth: Wolves are a constant danger to humans
myths.fact: Wolves are extremely wary of humans and actively avoid them. Fatal wolf attacks are extremely rare—fewer than 10 per decade worldwide, mostly in areas where wolves have lost their fear of humans.

myths.myth: Wolves howl at the moon
myths.fact: Wolves howl to communicate with pack members over long distances, establish territory, and coordinate hunts. The moon has nothing to do with it—they howl during the day and night.

name: Opossum
quickFacts: Opossums are North America's only marsupial
They have 50 teeth—more than any other North American mammal
Opossums rarely get rabies due to their low body temperature
ecologicalBenefits: Eat ticks that carry Lyme disease
Consume garden pests and rodents
Help clean up fallen fruit and carrion

myths.myth: Opossums are rabid and carry diseases
myths.fact: Opossums have a lower body temperature than most mammals, making it difficult for the rabies virus to survive. They're actually less likely to carry rabies than dogs or raccoons.

myths.myth: Opossums are dirty and play dead to trick predators
myths.fact: Opossums are clean animals that groom themselves regularly. Playing dead (thanatosis) is an involuntary response to extreme fear—they can't control it and may remain 'dead' for hours.

myths.myth: Opossums hang by their tails
myths.fact: While young opossums can briefly hang by their tails, adult opossums are too heavy. Their tails are mainly used for balance and carrying nesting materials.

name: Snake
quickFacts: There are over 3,000 species of snakes worldwide
Only about 600 species are venomous
Snakes help control rodent populations
ecologicalBenefits: Control rodent populations that damage crops
Reduce disease spread by controlling pest populations
Serve as important prey for other wildlife

myths.myth: All snakes are venomous and will attack humans
myths.fact: Most snakes are non-venomous, and even venomous snakes prefer to avoid humans. Snakes only bite when threatened, cornered, or stepped on. Most bites occur when people try to handle or kill snakes.

myths.myth: Snakes are slimy and aggressive
myths.fact: Snakes have smooth, dry scales—not slimy skin. They're generally shy and will retreat if given the opportunity. Aggressive behavior is usually defensive.

myths.myth: You can tell if a snake is venomous by its head shape
myths.fact: While some venomous snakes have triangular heads, this isn't reliable. Many non-venomous snakes flatten their heads when threatened, and some venomous snakes have rounded heads.

name: Rat
quickFacts: Rats are highly intelligent and social animals
They can learn complex tasks and show empathy
Rats have been used in medical research for decades
ecologicalBenefits: Help decompose organic matter
Serve as important prey for many predators
Aid in seed dispersal in some ecosystems

myths.myth: Rats are dirty and spread disease everywhere
myths.fact: Rats are actually very clean animals that groom themselves regularly. Disease transmission typically occurs through contact with their waste in unsanitary conditions, not through the animals themselves.

myths.myth: Rats are aggressive and will attack humans
myths.fact: Wild rats are shy and avoid humans. They only bite when cornered or threatened. Pet rats are gentle and can form strong bonds with humans.

myths.myth: Rats serve no purpose and should be eradicated
myths.fact: Rats play important ecological roles and are highly intelligent. They've contributed significantly to medical research, helping develop treatments for many human diseases.
